metadata.title: REIT Cycles and Valuation Knowledge
metadata.source: Compiled from Ralph Block, Brad Thomas, Nareit Research

chunks.title: Real Estate Market Cycle Phases
chunks.content:
Real estate moves through 4 distinct phases (Glenn Mueller model):

1. RECOVERY (Bottom to Growth)
- Occupancy rising from trough
- No new construction
- Rent growth begins
- Signal: Buy REITs aggressively

2. EXPANSION (Growth Phase)
- Occupancy above long-term average
- New construction begins
- Rent growth accelerates
- Signal: Hold, selective adds

3. HYPERSUPPLY (Peak to Decline)
- New supply exceeds demand
- Occupancy peaks, then falls
- Rent growth slows
- Signal: Reduce exposure, raise quality

4. RECESSION (Decline Phase)
- Occupancy falls below average
- No new construction starts
- Rent decline possible
- Signal: Defensive REITs only (healthcare, storage)

Cycle length: 7-10 years on average.

chunks.title: Interest Rate Impact on REITs
chunks.content:
REITs have complex relationship with interest rates:

RISING RATES (Negative short-term):
- Higher borrowing costs squeeze margins
- Cap rates expand → NAV declines
- Dividend yield less attractive vs bonds
- DEFENSIVE SECTORS outperform: Healthcare, Storage, Net Lease

FALLING RATES (Positive):
- Lower borrowing costs boost margins
- Cap rates compress → NAV rises
- Dividend yield more attractive
- GROWTH SECTORS outperform: Towers, Data Centers, Industrial

Key insight: Rate DIRECTION matters more than level. REITs can perform well at 5% rates if rates are falling.

Duration risk: Average REIT has 4-6 year duration. 1% rate rise → ~5% price decline (short-term).

chunks.title: FFO and AFFO Valuation
chunks.content:
REIT-specific valuation metrics:

FFO (Funds From Operations):
- Net income + Depreciation - Gains on property sales
- Standard REIT earnings metric
- P/FFO multiple: Average 15-18x for quality REITs

AFFO (Adjusted FFO):
- FFO - Recurring CapEx - Straight-line rent adjustments
- More conservative, reflects true cash flow
- Better for dividend sustainability analysis

Valuation signals:
- P/FFO < 12x: Potentially undervalued (or quality concern)
- P/FFO 15-18x: Fair value for quality
- P/FFO > 22x: Premium valuation, growth priced in

Payout ratio: AFFO payout < 85% = sustainable dividend. >90% = dividend risk.

chunks.title: REIT Sector Rotation Strategy
chunks.content:
Sector rotation based on economic regime:

EARLY CYCLE (Recovery):
- Best: Industrial, Residential, Hotels
- Avoid: Office (WFH impact), Retail (structural decline)

MID CYCLE (Expansion):
- Best: Data Centers, Towers, Industrial
- Avoid: Healthcare (rate sensitive)

LATE CYCLE (Hypersupply):
- Best: Net Lease (O, VICI), Healthcare (WELL)
- Avoid: Office, Hotels

RECESSION:
- Best: Storage (PSA), Net Lease (O), Healthcare
- Avoid: Hotels, Malls, Office

Our Tier 7 universe by regime:
- Rising Rates: O, VICI, PSA, WELL (Defensive)
- Falling Rates: AMT, CCI, DLR, EQIX, PLD (Growth)
- Neutral: Balanced allocation

chunks.title: Cap Rate Analysis
chunks.content:
Cap rate = NOI / Property Value. Key relationship: Cap rate moves INVERSE to property values.

Current cap rates by sector (Dec 2025):
- Industrial: 4.5-5.5% (compressed, high demand)
- Multifamily: 5.0-6.0%
- Office: 7.0-9.0% (wide spread due to WFH uncertainty)
- Retail: 6.0-8.0%
- Data Centers: 5.0-6.0%
- Healthcare: 6.0-7.0%

Signals:
- Cap rate < 5%: Premium pricing, growth expected
- Cap rate 6-7%: Fair value
- Cap rate > 8%: Distress or structural concerns

Spread to 10Y Treasury:
- Healthy: 200-300 bps spread
- Tight: <150 bps spread (REITs expensive)
- Wide: >400 bps spread (opportunity or distress)

chunks.title: Dividend Sustainability Analysis
chunks.content:
REIT dividend sustainability framework:

1. PAYOUT RATIO
- AFFO payout < 75%: Very safe, room for growth
- AFFO payout 75-85%: Safe, watch for deterioration
- AFFO payout 85-95%: Caution, limited margin
- AFFO payout > 95%: Dividend at risk

2. DEBT METRICS
- Debt/EBITDA < 5x: Conservative
- Debt/EBITDA 5-7x: Moderate
- Debt/EBITDA > 7x: Elevated leverage risk

3. DIVIDEND HISTORY
- Consecutive raises: Quality signal (O has 29 years)
- Recent cut: Red flag, investigate cause
- Frozen dividend: Stress or reinvestment phase

4. TENANT QUALITY
- Investment grade tenants: Stable cash flow
- Weighted average lease term (WALT) > 5 years: Good
- Top tenant < 10% of rent: Diversified

chunks.title: Our REIT Universe Analysis
chunks.content:
Tier 7 REIT universe breakdown:

GROWTH SECTORS (Rising Rates Underperform):
- AMT (American Tower): Cell towers, 5G growth, P/FFO ~20x
- CCI (Crown Castle): Towers + fiber, dividend focus
- DLR (Digital Realty): Data centers, AI/cloud demand
- EQIX (Equinix): Premium data centers, global footprint
- PLD (Prologis): Industrial/logistics, e-commerce play

DEFENSIVE SECTORS (Rising Rates Outperform):
- O (Realty Income): Monthly dividend, net lease, 29yr raises
- VICI (VICI Properties): Gaming/experiential, high yield
- PSA (Public Storage): Self-storage, recession-resistant
- WELL (Welltower): Senior housing, aging demographics

RESIDENTIAL:
- AVB (AvalonBay): Class A apartments, coastal markets
- EQR (Equity Residential): Similar to AVB
- INVH (Invitation Homes): Single-family rental, housing shortage play

chunks.title: REIT Tax Considerations
chunks.content:
REIT dividend taxation (important for allocation):

1. ORDINARY INCOME (majority of REIT dividends)
- Taxed at marginal income tax rate
- Can be 22-37% for high earners
- QBI deduction: 20% deduction available

2. CAPITAL GAINS (portion of some dividends)
- Taxed at long-term capital gains rate (0/15/20%)
- More tax-efficient

3. RETURN OF CAPITAL (reduces cost basis)
- Not immediately taxable
- Reduces basis, higher eventual capital gains

Portfolio implications:
- Hold REITs in tax-advantaged accounts (IRA, 401k) when possible
- If in taxable: Focus on REITs with higher capital gains/ROC portion
- Municipal REIT exposure (rare) can be tax-exempt
